pattern.analysis:
Looking at the three product examples, I need to identify the main container element that wraps each complete product. 

All three products share the same container structure:
- Element: `<x-cell>` (custom HTML element)
- Classes: `swiper-slide pro-card` (both classes appear on ALL products)
- Additional attributes: `prod-instock="true"` and `data-gender` (present on all)

The container element `<x-cell class="swiper-slide pro-card"` contains:
1. Product images with links
2. Product metadata including name in h2.card-title
3. Product links with href attributes

For the link selector, within each container there are multiple `<a>` elements, but the main product link is consistently found in the `h2.card-title` element as `h2.card-title a.no-style`.

For the name selector, the product name is contained within the same link element `h2.card-title a.no-style`.

The combination of custom element `x-cell` with the specific classes `swiper-slide pro-card` provides high specificity while the `prod-instock` attribute adds additional discrimination against non-product elements.

pattern.analysis:
Looking at the three product examples, I need to identify the main container element that wraps each complete product.

PRODUCT 1 (apex-wool-top-brown):
- Container: `<div class="es-character es-character--3">`
- Link: `<a href="https://www.entirestudios.com/product/apex-wool-top-brown" class="es-character-inner es-character-inner--blackout-countdown">`
- Name: Found in `.es-product-uniform-garment-title` containing "APEX WOOL TOP BROWN"

PRODUCT 2 (apex-wool-top-dust-grey):
- Container: `<div class="es-character es-character--8">`
- Link: `<a href="https://www.entirestudios.com/product/apex-wool-top-dust-grey" class="es-character-inner es-character-inner--blackout-countdown">`
- Name: Found in `.es-product-uniform-garment-title` containing "APEX WOOL TOP DUST GREY"

PRODUCT 3 (apex-wool-top-mustard):
- Container: `<div class="es-character es-character--5">`
- Link: `<a href="https://www.entirestudios.com/product/apex-wool-top-mustard" class="es-character-inner es-character-inner--blackout-countdown">`
- Name: Found in `.es-product-uniform-garment-title` containing "APEX WOOL TOP MUSTARD"

INTERSECTION ANALYSIS:
All three products share the same container structure:
- Main container: `div` with classes `es-character` (ALL have this)
- Each has a numbered variant like `es-character--3`, `es-character--8`, `es-character--5` (these are unique per product)
- All contain an `<a>` element with classes `es-character-inner` and `es-character-inner--blackout-countdown`

The most precise selector that captures ALL products is `div.es-character` since:
1. All products use a div element as the main container
2. All have the `es-character` class
3. The numbered variants (--3, --8, --5) are unique identifiers but not shared across all products

For links: All products have `a.es-character-inner.es-character-inner--blackout-countdown` within the container.

For names: All products have `.es-product-uniform-garment-title` containing the product name, but this can also be extracted from the URL structure.

pattern.analysis:
Looking at the three product examples, I need to identify the main container element that wraps each complete product.

For all three products, the main container is an `x-cell` element with specific attributes:
- Product 1: `<x-cell class="" prod-instock="false">`
- Product 2: `<x-cell class="" prod-instock="false">`  
- Product 3: `<x-cell class="" prod-instock="true">`

All products share:
1. The `x-cell` custom element (highly specific to this site's product grid)
2. The `prod-instock` attribute (product-specific data attribute)
3. A `class=""` attribute (though empty, it's consistently present)

This container wraps the complete product structure including:
- `.card-image` with product link and images
- `.card-meta` with vendor, title, and price information

For the product link, all products have the same structure: `a[href^="/products/"]` within the `.card-image` div.

For the product name, all products have: `h2.card-title.h4 > a.no-style` within the `.card-meta` section.

The `x-cell[prod-instock]` selector is highly specific because:
1. `x-cell` is a custom element unique to this site's framework
2. `prod-instock` is a product-specific data attribute
3. This combination is unlikely to match non-product elements

pattern.analysis:
Looking at the three product examples, I need to identify the main container element that wraps each complete product.

From the HTML analysis:

PRODUCT 1: The main container is `<product-card class="product-card text-left">` which contains the figure with images, product info div with vendor, title link, and pricing.

PRODUCT 2: Same structure - `<product-card class="product-card text-left">` containing figure, product-card-info div with all product details.

PRODUCT 3: Same structure - `<product-card class="product-card text-left">` containing figure, product-card-info div.

All three products share the exact same container element: `product-card` (custom HTML element) with classes "product-card" and "text-left".

For the link selector, within each product-card container, there are multiple links but the main product link is consistently found at `a.product-featured-image-link` (the image link) and `a.product-card-title` (the title link). The title link is more semantically appropriate for the main product link.

For the name selector, the product names are consistently found in `a.product-card-title` which contains the product title text.

The combination of the custom element `product-card` with the specific classes provides high specificity while being present across all products. This avoids generic layout classes and focuses on the semantic product container.

pattern.analysis:
Looking at the three product examples, I need to identify the main container element that wraps each complete product.

For each product, I can see the structure follows this pattern:
- Each product is wrapped in an `<li>` element with classes: "grid__item scroll-trigger animate--slide-in scroll-trigger--offscreen"
- Inside that is a `<div>` with classes: "card-wrapper product-card-wrapper underline-links-hover"

Let me analyze the classes that appear on ALL container elements:

Product 1 container: `<div class="card-wrapper product-card-wrapper underline-links-hover">`
Product 2 container: `<div class="card-wrapper product-card-wrapper underline-links-hover">`  
Product 3 container: `<div class="card-wrapper product-card-wrapper underline-links-hover">`

All three products have the exact same container element with classes: "card-wrapper", "product-card-wrapper", and "underline-links-hover".

This container is the most precise selector as it:
1. Uses multiple specific classes that appear on ALL products
2. The "product-card-wrapper" class is semantically meaningful for products
3. Combines three classes for high specificity to avoid false matches

For the link selector, within each container I can see consistent `<a>` elements with class "full-unstyled-link" that contain the product URLs.

For the name selector, the product names appear in the link text and can be extracted from the URLs, so I'll set this to null as URL extraction is preferred.

pattern.analysis:
Looking at the three product examples, I need to identify the main container element that wraps each complete product. 

Analyzing the HTML structure:
- Product 1: The main container is `<div class="filter-vip product-block cc-product-block hover-image product-block--quickbuy column quintin cc-initialized">`
- Product 2: The main container is `<div class="filter-vip product-block cc-product-block hover-image product-block--quickbuy column quintin cc-initialized">`  
- Product 3: The main container is `<div class="filter-vip product-block cc-product-block hover-image product-block--quickbuy column quintin cc-initialized">`

All three products share the exact same classes on their main container element: `filter-vip`, `product-block`, `cc-product-block`, `hover-image`, `product-block--quickbuy`, `column`, `quintin`, and `cc-initialized`.

For maximum specificity, I'll combine the most distinctive classes that clearly identify this as a product block. The combination of `product-block`, `cc-product-block`, and `product-block--quickbuy` provides strong semantic meaning and specificity.

For the product link, each container has an `<a>` element with `href` pointing to the product URL. The most reliable selector is `a[href*="/products/"]` within the container.

For the product name, each product has a `<span class="title ProductBlock__Title">` containing the product name. This provides a highly specific selector for name extraction.

pattern.analysis:
Looking at the three product examples, I need to identify the main container element that wraps each complete product.

For all three products, the main container structure is:
- `<li>` element with classes: "col-6 col-sm-3 mb-2 mb-sm-4 -brand-mm single-element show-second-image even"
- Contains a `<div class="product">` with data-pid attribute
- Inside that is `<article class="product-brand mm-product-card -brand-mm">`

The most precise container that encompasses each complete product is the `<article>` element with classes "product-brand mm-product-card -brand-mm". This element contains:
1. The product link (single-element-content-image)
2. The product name (in the tile-body section)
3. All product-specific content

All three products share these exact same classes on their article element:
- product-brand
- mm-product-card  
- -brand-mm

For the product link, all products have an `<a>` element with class "single-element-content-image" that contains the product URL.

For the product name, all products have an `<a>` element with classes "product-link mm-product-card__title product-card-title" that contains the product name text.

The combination of these three classes (product-brand.mm-product-card.-brand-mm) provides high specificity while being present on all product containers.

pattern.analysis:
Looking at the three product examples, I need to identify the main container element that wraps each complete product.

For all three products, the main container structure is:
- `<article class="c-product" data-pid="[PRODUCT_ID]">` - This is the outermost product container
- Inside this is `<div class="c-product__item">` - This contains all product elements (wishlist, swatches, link, etc.)

The `<article>` element has:
- Class: "c-product" (consistent across all products)
- Attribute: data-pid with unique product IDs ("845978WBDH09320", "845393WA9191080", "8468752AB5Q1000")

The main product link is:
- `<a class="c-product__focus" href="[PRODUCT_URL]" data-action="handlePLPProduct" data-ref="link" itemprop="url" data-pid="[PRODUCT_ID]">`

The product name is found in:
- `<h2 class="c-product__name">` containing the product name text

For maximum specificity, I'll target the article element with both its semantic class and the data-pid attribute. The link selector will target the specific anchor with its distinctive classes and attributes. The name selector will target the h2 with the specific product name class.

All products share the same structural pattern with consistent class names, making this a reliable selector pattern.
